Noting the significant species differences in the toxicity of 1,3-butadiene (BD), four groups of researchers developed physiologically based toxicokinetic (PBTK) models of BD in mice and rats. These models were developed on the premise that differences in the circulating concentrations of epoxybutene (butadiene monoepoxide, EB), and/or diepoxybutane (butadiene diepoxide, DEB) may be responsible for induction of tumors in mice at much lower exposure concentrations than were necessary to produce tumors in the rat. Blood concentrations of diepoxide alone may not entirely explain the differences in carcinogenicity, but they most likely play an important role. In June, 1998, the Chemical Industry Institute of Technology (CIIT) Workshop on Physiologically Based Pharmacokinetic Modeling of 1,3-Butadiene convened.
